caption: This small bridge links the tow islands of Ile de Cite and Ile de saint-Louis, very handy for us walking types.

I didn‚Äôt know there is a bridge between two island because it doesn‚Äôt look existing on the Google Maps. It‚Äôs pedestrian only bridge but wide enough for the car traffic. There were some old people enjoying roller skating slalom! üòÜ
Amazing bridge connecting the two islands in paris. On nice days you can find many a street artist here and it's fun to just sit down and enjoy some time here.

Easily my favorite bridge to watch street performers play for hours on end. Today I managed to listen to a Latin cover of Ne Me Quittes Pas whilst two lovers passionately embraced.  Oh, and a father swung his child around upside down. It was cute...and mayyyybe unsafe üòÇ

Sweet little bridge connecting I'le de la Cit√© and I'le Saint Louis. We walked it all times of day and night and never tired of the views. Cafes nearby on both side and a great view of the Seine and Notre Dame. Even though it was winter we had street museums on Sat morning. It was even nice in the rain.

It's a cosy place to visit in the evening. You have a beautiful view on the river. To your side is the Notre Dame in all it's glory. And on the bridge are street artists and street performer showing of their talent. If you want a relaxing night you should go there. Don't forget to buy and enjoy an ice cream.

A bridge across the River Seine in the 4th arrondissement. It links the √éle de la Cit√© with the √éle Saint-Louis. The present bridge is the seventh to link the two islands since 1630. The pont Saint-Landry (1630‚Äì1634) was the first of these.  In 1717 a wooden bridge was rebuilt, with seven arches, and named the "Pont Rouge", due to the colour in which it was painted. It was destroyed in 1795. In 1804, under the direction of the engineer Dumoustier, a new two-arch bridge was built, 70 m long and 10 m wide, and mainly in oak. It was demolished in 1811, and a suspension bridge replaced it in 1842. Twenty years later, this was replaced by a metallic bridge, with a single arch with a 64m opening. In 1939, this one was demolished. In 1941, it was replaced by a "passerelle" resembling an iron cage. In 1968, the present bridge was begun, and inaugurated in 1970.
Not sure if this is the actual bridge, but Google says so... Was wondering Paris one evening and came across this guy playing piano in the middle of the bridge. Was a fun little random event :)
Great little bridge for a stroll with frequent performing street artist leading you to the famed Berthillon sorbet shop (best sorbet in France)
Very good view at Notre-Dame.
great bridge to watch notre dame closely
When there with my friends of the 1e Infanterie Regiment when one of them accidentally talking to a man name Jean who was evacuating Parisian out of the area
Super beautiful sunset there. One of my favorite bridges in Paris!
I took the train from sant louis to Paris in 1999
Romantic, colorful, entertaining,relaxing, elegant!!
The obvious. One of the bridges. For pedestrians only. Nice buildings around.
Nice spot to shoot photo
More utilitarian in style, but there is a lot of life here

Small, quaint bridge connecting the two islands.  Beautiful views from behind Notre Dame.  Even more stunning when viewed at night.  There are often street performers livening up the bridge and area.   Nice way to traverse and see both side of the islands and get unique vantage points.

Nice views out either way over the Seine river. Generally heavy traffic, though there is a path on each side for walking and biking. Along the path part-way however it spans out with sharp turns so this is both difficult to navigate for bikes plus has blind spots at each corner so it's not possible to see who is coming from the other direction. Otherwise, the structure is solid and attractive, especially the soft lighting at night down the sides.

Charming bridge with live music and street performers year round. Lovely for walks between the two islands of Paris and plenty of nice spots nearby to watch the river or sit and have a picnic in the evening, as the locals do.

Nice place to get the two islands together. Been there yesterday for the first time in my life, in the St Louis island  and gotta say its a very nice spot in the city and I recommend using this bridge to realize what you see when you are using a boat in the Seine river.

Just sat over lunch looking across at Notre Dame.  Good to see work in progress to stabilise the structure. Each generation has added something of its own to these iconic buildings.  France did a wonderful job on the Louvres. Look forward to seeing what this generation of architects has to offer
i love the quaibt little boutique shops along the street

If you really want to see interesting  sculptures, then go. But there's really nothing of the house to see. It's more of a gallery than a museum though sculptures not for sale. Not worth the walk.

When people come visit in Paris, we love to show them this spot. Great views, it's cosy, and there's often street artist busy. Funny little place.
nice view from here
Nice old bridge.

Although Paris doesn't have a river view in quite the same way as looking east from the Hungerford Bridge in London, the scene from this bridge is about as iconic as one gets from the Seine in Paris. Some of the unauthorized traders can be pushy. Cross late at night to hear musically talented buskers on some occasions.
Beautiful spot to be right after sunset. Enjoying the the surrounding architecture of the buildings and lights reflecting on the water below.
Parisian bridges are part of the extraordinary power and beauty of this city. Pont Saint Louis is one of the main exquisite bridges. A must see, walk and feel Paris through 5 senses.

One of the must go when you walk through Paris streets : a beautiful view connecting Cit√© and Saint-louis Islands... find there some typical parisian caf√©s and small streets that gives us an idea of how Paris looked like a century ago...
My favorite bridge in Paris.  Great views.  No vehicles.  Great jazz music from street performers most days.

Swans on the Seine! We fed them bread and they came out of the wayer: large and gentle, quite a show for the people on the ramp at the foot of the bridge... Always a good sign to see ferals not afraid of the people. Civilization!
Glimpse of the damage to Notre Dame. Places to rest and relax.
Its such a great place to take romantic walks especially during summer eves... i loved listening to some of the talented street artists.
